{"title":"Section 5, Page 2","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"2
I will add but a word or two: Choose no man for your servant from farm
or affection, or hope of reward, but in consideration of his capacity, integrity,
and fitness for the duties he may be called to perform, so that our great enter-
prise may progress in the go-ahead spirit of our country, and have from even!
patriotic and liberal mind an earnest " God-speed."
The President then requested the Vice Presidents and
Secretaries (a list of whose names was read) to take their
places on the stand.
VICE PRESIDENTS :
Hon. J. H. Overton, St. Landry.
Gen. DeClouet, St. Martin.
Ex-Gov. Mouton, Lafayette.
H. Cornay, St. Mary.
J. W. Tucker, Lafourche.
Dr. Ketridge, Assumption.
W. J. Minor, Terrebonne.
D. F. Kenner, Ascension.

Charles H. Flower, Kapides.
Gen. Thomas F. Williamson, DeSoto.
Gen. Henry Phillips, Sabine.
SECRETARIES :
J. E. King, St. Landry.
D. Hawkins, St. Mary.
B. F. Flanders, New Orleans.
Wm. A. Gordon, New Orleans.
John Burns, New Orleans.
Robert Taylor, Lafayette.
